narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is really aimed at giving students a better understanding of sleep disorders, the history of sleep, and sleep in general.

I learned a lot about sleep and how sleep research is conducted. we also got to learn about sleep in art which was super cool. I have a much better understanding of sleep and sleeps function in our lives and my sleep habits have improved tremendously
I learned a lot about the mechanisms of sleep, as well as the way that sleep and dreams have been interpreted in philosophy, art, and psychology.
I learned a lot about sleep which is something that people take for granted
An understanding of sleep science and the effects of sleep on people.
I learned nothing
I learned a lot about how to maximize my sleep and how to have healthy sleep habits.

there was of course the science stuff, which I probably will not remember. but I will 100% remember that SLEEP IS SO IMPORTANT (which sounds obvious but this class DRILLS IT into you, 6.5 hours just wont cut it) and the host of practical tips about improving sleep.
A foundational understanding of sleep science
I learned a lot about sleep science, improving sleep habits, and lots of sleep facts.
Learning the basics of sleep science, science of sleep disorders, and the importance of sleep.
Better understanding of human sleep, useful for understanding your own body to organize your sleep better

I knew sleep was important, but that was as far as my knowledge on the subject went. Now, I consider myself passionate about the topic. In one of our closing lectures, Professor Kryger told us that, going forward, we'd all be advocates for better sleep. I've already found that to be true. Not only have I learned on an intellectual level, but I've also been able to reconsider and improve my sleeping habits. 
You learn interesting material that you can immediately apply to your own life.
I enjoyed learning about sleep habits and was able to improve my own sleep from this course.
I learnt a lot of sleep, the science of sleep and the human body, how to improve my own sleeping habits and how to help other people with their own sleep
I learned how to read scientific papers and think critically about problems in science.

I learned more about the history of sleep in art and literature, as well as the neuroscience behind sleep. Besides the interesting facts learned in the class, the best part of the subject material was learning tips on how to improve my own sleep and the sleep health of my family and friends.

I learned about the history of sleep science, including the art and philosophy surrounding sleep, theories of sleep pre-science, and recent developments in the field (like the discovery of clock genes in fruit flies). Moreover, I wrote my first scientific research paper here, and engaged with sleep science through creative pursuits like team projects and writing a short story (for the midterm paper). I gained much insight into the way the human body reacts to sleep (and the lack of sleep) and the mechanisms by which those bodily (and mental) reactions occur. This course definitely taught me to value getting more sleep more, and why (and gives the tools for getting better sleep).
I learned about the history of sleep and sleep theory/dreams. It was a science credit, but also had really interesting non-scientific components in philosophy, art, etc.
A survey understanding of sleep across academic disciplines, but most deeply rooted in the cognitive and biological study of the subject.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course material is interesting but often felt disorganised. It felt at times like there were only 3-4 lectures throughout the semester that covered 95% of the material with the other lectures being full of repetition.

I wish there was more guidance for assignments. I loved that they were so open-ended, but it also made it very challenging to know where to start, especially for the science paper. Overall the class was amazing though and definitely the best science credit I could have ever chosen

Strengths: I really liked the sessions where we talked about the basics: the biology of sleep, circadian rhythms, sleep disorders, and insomnia/its treatments. At its best, this class made me really aware of 1) how much sleep I need, 2) how cool the mechanisms of sleep are, and 3) how much we still dont know about sleep  how it is, truly, a mystery.

Weaknesses: I wasnt a huge fan of the way that the course was organized. I felt like the topics could have been ordered in a better sequence. In the beginning, felt that we spent too much time on literature/sleep/philosophy, the history of sleep medicine, and What is science vs. the humanities. Then, the guest lectures on sleep in animals and sleep in communities with and without electricity were a bit dry to me, but they may actually have been better received at the end of the course, after we had already covered the basics of What is sleep and how does it work in humans? As it stands, the course got better as we approached the second half, when we really got into the biology of sleep, circadian rhythms, sleep disorders, and their treatments. 

One more small note: while I appreciated the enthusiastic inclusion of humanities majors, I think that the instructors may have leaned a little bit too heavily on the STEM/humanities divide. Dont worry, if you study the humanities, youll be OK felt patronizing after a while.
Too long of a zoom lecture

Strengths: guest lecturers, topic, explanations, supportive professors, freedom for curiosity, and exploration of  interests

Weaknesses: structure often unclear, unclear grading and lacking rubrics/direction for essays and projects, lack of adequate communication about assignments with students

Strengths: good sci credit for non-STEM kids
Weaknesses: takes itself much too seriously, highly repetitive, there are two profs and way too many guest lectures so the course has no consistent narrative, for some reason they find it necessary to assign a final paper, final exam, and final group project

Strengths: interesting topic, low workload during most of the semester, and our professors were very nice. Weaknesses: very unorganized, I wish we had more information on canvas about what was expected of our assignments. Also, it was unfortunately difficult to engage with this class in its online lecture structure.

strengths: the professors clearly care so deeply about the course and their students. guest lectures are great. incorporation of humanities cool-ish. practical takeaways (e.g. lecture w lynelle scheeberg (sp?)) are reeeeeaaaallllly helpful. learning how to do a sleep log. ACTIONABLE INSIGHTS! and animal lectures.

weaknesses: seems to be a sorta inordinate amount of work, in the last week (final paper, final exam, final project)

There were many guest lecturers that repeated some things we had already learned about. I was very anxious about the multiple-choice exams because I had no idea what we were going to get tested on. We did not receive feedback on our exams. We only received the right answers without finding out which ones we got wrong.

The professors are lovely people clearly passionate about their subject, and they bring a wealth of knowledge to the course. There are three final assessments (a paper, a project, and an exam). It would be nice if these components are spaced out more in the future. Also, I felt like the exam questions were perhaps too specific at times. And, I wish we heard back on our exam scores and essay scores sooner so that we could incorporate the feedback into our learning.

Very good introductory course to sleep with an emphasis on not being too STEM heavy for non-STEM students. However, the class felt a bit disorganized. Often times something would be mentioned and then it was said "you don't know this but we'll review it in another class" which was disorienting. The class needs better organization and flow of topics.

Strengths: The course approaches the topic with the assumption that college science is unfamiliar to many of the students. This meant that they teach at a slow pace and make the lessons clear. It also isn't an extremely technical science class and the curriculum also teaches about sleep in art, philosophy, and literature as well. Very light workload which was appreciated during the pandemic.

Zoom sometimes made it difficult to always stay forcused during lecture.

The strength is the people teaching. Dr. Kryger, Dr. Baddam, and all the TF's were incredibly passionate about the material, and that excitement came out in our lectures, discussions, and even assignments.

No real weaknesses of the course, guest lecturers and content was interesting assignments were engaging and diverse. The final project could have a higher weighting because it was very enjoyable and I think students responded really well to it
The expectations for the written assignments could have been made a bit clearer.
Great class with really interesting material but a LOT of work

Because of the online format, it was a bit more difficult to engage during class. The lectures were larger and less inviting for participation. It could be improved by breaking up lectures into smaller discussion sections to invite more discourse about the subject material.

Strengths:
- Easily accessible materials
- Instructors had wonderful teaching styles, obvious enthusiasm for and experience in their field, highly personable in talking with students
- Well-rounded syllabus gives holistic view of sleep science

Weaknesses:
- Instructors could have helped groups form for the term project; many students were panicking in the last weeks because they had no groups to do the term project with (eventually it was all resolved but there was, in my opinion, unnecessary confusion).

Strength: Great professors

Weakness: Exams were a little tricky but the projects and problem sets for the sleep logs are good boosts.
Readings felt unnecessarily dense as they did not relate to class assignments in any way. The combination of essays and exams in the same week felt overwhelming.

weekly workload was great. however, having a final assessment, project, and essay would be a lot to end a regular semester (let alone one conducted over zoom/remotely). I would consider emphasizing two of the three, especially considering that most students are not cognitive science majors with an incredibly deep understanding of sleep. I believe it would eliminate redundancy in final work. Also, more in-depth rubrics for expected work would be very helpful for future students, I can assure.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The online lectures were as successful as an in-person lecture would have been. However, the discussion days were less successful in my opinion.

I think that the instructors of this course probably could have done more to adjust the pedagogy of the course toward online learning. I wish that we had spent more than one and a half sessions in breakout rooms  perhaps the breakout rooms could even have been consistent, with the same students paired up with the same TF/professor  and even some time spent freewriting or doing other more interactive exercises could have helped vary the class structure.
The class was good
Could be improved by making quizzes to go along with the lecture to keep students engaged.

I feel like this class would have been better as a seminar, it was difficult to feel like you were getting something out of it when you were expected to engage in a 60-person class. I feel like we should have used breakout rooms more often.
i dont know how a lecture could be better in the covid era, I liked the surveys to keep ppl engaged but feel like those sort of dropped off towards the end
I wish the lecture videos were uploaded more consistently and sooner so that we could review them.

I would've enjoyed some smaller discussions in Zoom breakout rooms, but otherwise, I thought the course did as good a job as possible given the circumstances. We got some great guest lecturers over Zoom.
Virtual lecture was good, projects went well online and otherwise the course ran relatively normally
The live, recorded lecture model worked well and the online quizzes were easily navigated.

The guest speakers were particularly interesting. Because everything was virtual, the course was able to invite a variety of notable speakers to teach us about sleep. Again, levels of participation could be improved.

Successes:
- Recorded lectures
- Slides posted on Canvas

Room for improvement:
- Lectures could be uploaded a bit faster
We never actually had our discussion sections/groups used that much.
Cameras should not have had to been kept on during lectures.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely. If you have sleep issues or just feel like you don't get enough sleep, this course will explain why and show you how to fix it. If you already have good sleep, the material is extremely interesting and the course is taught in a fun way.
Yes!

Yes absolutely. If you are not a STEM major and you need a science credit this is perfect for you. Dr. Kryger and Dr. Baddam tailor this course to nonmajors and it's absolutely perfect and really facilitates a comfortable learning environment. Also, everyone needs sleep, and college students sleep horribly, so it was incredibly beneficially for my personal sleep hygiene and I've taught my friends and family so much from it

I would recommend this course to a student whos looking for an interesting science credit thats useful and applicable to their lives. At its best, this class made me really aware of 1) how much sleep I need, 2) how cool the mechanisms of sleep are, and 3) how much we still dont know about sleep  how it is, truly, a mystery. If nothing else, the course will show you how much humans NEED sleep  and for Yale students, the more convinced you are of that fact, the better. Dr. Kryger and Dr. Baddam are solid, old-school professors. Their teaching style wasnt necessarily the most dynamic  it was a pretty standard Powerpoint slides + lecture format, but hey, it worked. I felt like the exams were both fair, but multiple choice seems like an outdated format when people have so many different learning styles. Finally, the combination of a final exam, project, and paper was a bit much, but I suppose it can be nice to have many different graded assignments so that each one carries less weight.
Yes it was very interesting and the material is useful
Its a good and interesting class that could also help you improve your sleep. Tests are basically half memorization dumps and half application.
Only take this if you want a fake science credit. Otherwise, do not waste your time

I did come out of it knowing more about sleep and the class was not very stressful, so yes. However, this class was not as impactful as I hoped it would be. I feel like maybe it would have been more impactful had it been in smaller sections, and if we actually used breakout rooms to discuss what we learned in a smaller group setting.
yes - extremely practical, actionable insights that will improve your sleep quality and life. very accepting (in fact, geared towards) non-stem majors.

If they are genuinely interested in sleep science, yes. If they are looking for an easy science, no. The class requires a lot more work than it seems, and you should only take it if you want to invest a lot of time into learning about sleep.

I think the topic itself is very important. However, the class itself wasn't always extremely engaging and is sometimes disorganized. Overall, every yale student should be exposed to the information of this class.

Yes! If you are a non-STEM student looking for a SC credit, this course is for you. I absolutely hate science classes and was very afraid to fulfill my SC credit, but this class was interesting and the coursework was very manageable. You do have to study for the two tests, but the professors make it clear what needs to be reviewed. Also, the professors clearly value learning over grades, so they designed the grade work to reflect your work by including a few different kinds of assignments (two creative ones!) and made sure that the weight of the tests does not sink your grade.

Yes! As a non-STEM person, I was a little traumatized by my first science credit. That's how I ended up in this class. And, If you need a science credit, this is a very manageable course that does not expect its students to know much going in. 
That being said, this far exceeded my expectations. It went from my science credit to a class I was always excited for, and maybe one of the more practical classes I've taken at Yale. I highly recommend if you're even remotely interested in sleep.
Yes, very interesting, professors are great and the assignments are engaging
Yes, this was a great science class for a non-stem major.
yes! Great science credit

I would recommend this course to another student. The professors emphasized the importance of bettering and learning about our sleep health over stressing about a grade. This helped create a very comfortable learning environment where purely learning was at the forefront of the class's agenda.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student, especially because college students often have unhealthy sleeping habits and there is a bad culture of taking pride in pushing one's body to the limits through sleeping less. Every student will benefit from learning why sleep is important and how more sleep improves performance.
Great science credit in comparison to doing harder science classes

The course itself was very interesting and actually improved my knowledge on sleep, my sleep habits, etc. So yes I would certainly recommend the class if someone were interested in taking it for those reasons.
